paragraph.value: Table 2 shows micro F1 scores on 5 out-domain test sets. Besides ours, only Cheng and Roth (2013) employs several mention relations. Mentnorm achieves the
F1 scores on MSNBC and ACE2004. On average, ment-norm's F1 score is
higher than that of Ganea and Hofmann (2017), but
lower than Guo and Barbosa (2016)'s. It is worth noting that Guo and Barbosa (2016) performs exceptionally well on WIKI, but substantially
than ment-norm on all other datasets. Our other three models, however, have
average F1 scores compared to the
previous model.  The experimental results show that ment-norm outperforms rel-norm, and that mention padding plays an important role.
